title: Repair Attempts
description: Explore how you try to de-escalate and reconnect during conflict.

questions.text: When conflict is escalating, I try to de-escalate by...
choices: Using humor or lightness to break tension
Saying 'I'm sorry' or 'I didn't mean it that way'
Reaching out physically (touch, hand-hold)
Asking to start over or slow down

therapeutic.rationale: Repair attempts are bids to de-escalate conflict. Humor breaks tension; apologies soften; physical touch reconnects; restart requests reset. Successful repair attempts predict relationship success more than conflict frequency.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different repair styles are all valid. Learn to recognize your partner's repair attempts even if different from yours.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared repair style makes de-escalation feel natural and coordinated.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you try to de-escalate when conflict is getting too intense?

questions.text: When my partner tries to de-escalate during conflict, I usually...
choices: Appreciate it and respond positively
Sometimes miss it in the moment
Find it hard to shift gears that quickly
Depend on whether I'm still too upset

therapeutic.rationale: Receiving repair attempts is as important as making them. Appreciators allow de-escalation; missers need awareness; gear-shift-strugglers need time; upset-dependers have conditions. Rejected repairs predict relationship failure.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different reception patterns need different approaches. The misser needs help recognizing repairs; the gear-shift-struggler needs patience.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared repair reception creates predictable de-escalation.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you respond when your partner tries to make things better during conflict?

questions.text: A repair attempt that works well for me is when my partner...
choices: Acknowledges my feelings are valid
Takes some responsibility
Shows affection or reaches for me
Uses humor to lighten things

therapeutic.rationale: Effective repairs vary by person. Validation works for some; responsibility-taking works for others; affection reconnects; humor lightens. Knowing what works for your partner helps you repair effectively.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different repair preferences require different giving. Learn what actually works for your partner, not what works for you.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared repair preference makes successful repair more likely.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What repair attempt from your partner would help you de-escalate? Have you told them?

questions.text: The thing that makes it hard to accept repair attempts is...
choices: I'm still too upset to shift
It feels like they're trying to end it too fast
I don't feel heard enough yet
I struggle to let go of my position

therapeutic.rationale: Barriers to accepting repair prevent de-escalation. Upset-stuckness needs time; too-fast-ending feels dismissive; not-heard-yet needs more listening; position-attachment is ego. Naming barriers helps address them.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different barriers need different solutions. The not-heard-yet partner needs more listening before repair; the too-upset partner needs pause.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared barriers help you understand why repairs sometimes fail.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes it hard for you to accept your partner's repair attempts? What would help?

questions.text: I want us to get better at repair attempts because...
choices: Conflict shouldn't damage our connection
I want us to recover quickly from disagreements
I don't like how bad things can get
Repair shows we value each other more than being right

therapeutic.rationale: Motivation for repair reflects relationship values. Connection-protectors prioritize relationship; quick-recoverers value efficiency; damage-limiters prevent harm; value-demonstrators show priorities. All motivations support repair skill development.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different motivations can all drive improvement. What matters is commitment to better repair.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared motivation aligns your reasons for developing repair skills.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Why do you want to get better at repairing during conflict? What would be different?
